title: Do People Like Their Mental Health Care?
summary:
Key ideas
- People who took the SSC survey rated their experience with psychotherapy and medication with a 5.7 on average.
- Only 7% of people had ever been involuntarily committed to a psychiatric hospital out of those who had seen a psychiatrist or therapist.
- People liked doing therapy from books the most, followed by in-person therapy and online therapy apps the least.
- People with bipolar and ADHD were happier with medication than therapy while alcoholics preferred therapy.
- Autistic people strongly prefer medication perhaps due to hating the social interaction involved in therapy.

Key learnings
- None of the numbers measure whether treatment works, just whether patients were happy.
- All results are vulnerable to selection effects and biases.

Key questions
- What percent of people engaging with the mental health system ended up inpatient based on the survey results?
- Why did autistics prefer medication over therapy?
- Why did people strongly prefer doing therapy from books compared to online therapy apps?
